feat.name: Speak of the Devil
entries: When you hear a creature within 30 feet of you say your name, you can use your reaction to teleport to an available space within 5 feet of the creature. You can do this a number of times equal to your charisma modifier. You regain all expended uses of this feature after completing a long rest.
这把武器蕴含着剑客大师的精神，他渴望传授更精细的技术。你在使用此武器的攻击卷和伤害卷上获得+1的奖励。它有以下的附加属性。

items.name: First Lesson
entries: 如果你还没有这种武器，你将获得这种武器的熟练度。

items.name: Watch My Hands
entries: 当你用此武器攻击时掷出自然1，空灵之手会重新调整你的姿态，在你下一回合结束前，在你下次使用此武器时给予你优势（%0%）。

items.name: Student and Master
entries: 当你用这把武器攻击时，掷出自然20分，一把幽灵剑与你自己的剑同时出击，使攻击造成额外的{@damage 1d8}魔法斩击伤害。这个额外的伤害不会因为关键打击而翻倍。

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: An object's hit points measure how much damage it can take before losing its structural integrity. Resilient objects have more hit points than fragile ones. Large objects also tend to have more hit points than small ones, unless breaking a small part of the object is just as effective as breaking the whole thing. The {@table Object Hit Points|ASRT} table (based on {@table Object Hit Points|DMG|the one from pg247 of the DMG}) provides suggested hit points for fragile and resilient objects that are Huge or smaller.

When using the {@table Object Hit Points|ASRT} table, first decide if the object is built stronger or weaker than normal, or has deteorated over time. A wooden gate at the entrance ofa cemetery is likely to have rotted over time, whereas the fence ofa new farm raising buffalo will have been built to withstand charges by the livestock. A fragile object will have half the HP ofa normal object, and a resilient object double.
The size of your object determines the number of dice to roll for its hit points, and the material the object is made of determines which die is used.

A normal door using this chart would have 14 ({@dice 4d6}) hit points. A strong metal door that might appear in a jail or a crypt would have 44 ({@dice 8d10}) hit points. If the party tries to break a padlock on a chest, it would have 22 ({@dice 4d10}) hit points, likely taking a few hits to break.

entries.name: Damage Threshold
entries: Large objects such as castle walls often have extra resilience represented by a damage threshold. An object with a damage threshold has immunity to all damage unless it takes an amount of damage from a single attack or effect equal to or greater than its damage threshold, in which case it takes damage as normal. Any damage that fails to meet or exceed the object's damage threshold is considered superflcial and doesn't reduce the object's hit points. The {@table Damage Threshold *|ASRT|Damage Threshold} table sets minimum damage thresholds for different material types.

If an adventurer decides to break down a stone castle wall with his maul, he will have to deal 20 or more damage on a hit for the attack to do substantial damage to the structure and reduce the object's hit points. This likely means a maul alone will not be able to break through the walls ofa dungeon or fortress before the weapon itself breaks.

entries.name: Magical Objects
entries: Most magical items and objects are of extraordinary artisanship. Thanks to a combination of careful crafting and magical reinforcement, a magic item is at least as durable as a nonmagical item of its kind.
Other than potions and scrolls, most magical items have resistance to all damage.
